titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Andrew Keogh Papers
titlestmt.author: compiled by Thomas J. Connors

publicationstmt.publisher: Yale University. Department of Manuscripts and Archives

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Thursday January 10, 2019 at 10:34

repository.corpname: Yale University. Department of Manuscripts and Archives

did.abstract: Chiefly memoranda, outlines, notes, bibliographies, newspaper clippings, and other materials relating to the courses in bibliography that Keogh taught at Yale University from 1924 to 1938. There is also a small amount of personal correspondence, 1898-1916.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Andrew Keogh Papers (MS 940). Manuscripts and Archives, Yale University Library.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Andrew Keogh Papers consist largely of memos, outlines, notes, bibliographies, newspaper clippings and other materials pertaining to the courses in bibliography that Keogh taught at Yale from 1924 to 1938. The papers are arranged alphabetically by subject, the titles in quotations being Keogh's original folder titles.

A folder of correspondence, for the most part personal letters to Keogh and coinciding with his early years at the Yale Library, follows the bibliographical material. Other letters, some to Keogh, some copies of letters from him, are filed in the subject folders under the topic which they specifically concern.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Andrew Keogh: reference librarian, Newcastle (Eng.) Public Libraries, 1892-1898; librarian of Linonia and Brothers Library at Yale University, 1899-1900; Yale University reference librarian, 1900-1916; Yale Librarian, 1916-1938; librarian emeritus, 1938-1953; lecturer and then professor of bibliography, 1902-1938; professor emeritus, 1938-1953.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Copyright status for collection materials is unknown. Transmission or reproduction of materials protected by U.S. Copyright Law (Title 17, U.S.C.) beyond that allowed by fair use requires the written permission of the copyright owners. Works not in the public domain cannot be commercially exploited without permission of the copyright owners. Responsibility for any use rests exclusively with the user.
